NPR's business news begins with a housing drop.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Sales of new homes plunged in the month of March, to the lowest pace since last July.
The harsh, never-ending winter may have been partly to blame, but the sluggish economy and the fact that it's still tough to get a mortgage made things especially difficult for some buyers.
There was also sticker shock, as the median price of new homes hit a record $290,000.
A thaw might be occurring now that we're into April.
Some homebuilders say things are, indeed, looking up.
New U.S.
poverty numbers will be coming out in a few weeks, and the numbers will almost certainly fuel the debate over how the government spends money on the poor.
The government's formula to define poverty has not evolved with the changing economy.
And as Planet Money's Pam Fessler reports, it can be pretty surprising to learn who's considered, quote, ""poor,"" and who's not.
Meet Rico Saccoccio: 20 years old, a junior at Fordham University in the Bronx - pretty middle class.
We are from Cheshire, Connecticut, which was recently voted the 34th nicest place to live, or something like that.
He often goes home for a good meal and a break from the city.
His parents cover about $15,000 a year in college costs.
But according to the U.S.
government, Saccoccio is living in poverty.
The $8,000 he earns doing odd jobs puts him well below the $12,000 individual poverty line.
That's the case for more than half of all college students who live off-campus and not at home.
And Saccoccio would say he's certainly not rich.
He's a struggling student with lots of loans, and he lives in an apartment that's kind of iffy.
I'm topping out these days at low 40s.
And you're on a skateboard on a public street, going downhill, no pads, no helmet.
And I don't think of Okkervil as an innovative band.
They just take this form, this solid form of great songwriting, and they just make it still work.
And I think that's pretty great that this form still holds true.

There's a song called ""Stay Young."" The sentiment in this song is about no matter how kind of awful and awkward he might have felt, Will Sheff, as a child growing up in this small town, he still looks back and he says it's still something to hold onto and something to get through.
And he did.
He found his little niche.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""STAY YOUNG"")

This is MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Relief from the resolution of the debt crisis didn't last long.
Congress has finished its game of chicken over raising the federal debt ceiling, but the battle shook world markets, and grim economic reports keep coming in.
NPR's Tom Gjelten reports on the challenges ahead.
Over the last several weeks, Washington's been so focused on the wrangling over the debt ceiling that other economic issues went largely unheeded.
Turns out, the U.S.
economy this year hasn't been performing nearly as well as we thought it was.
The GDP barely grew in the first two quarters.
Manufacturing is in worse shape than we realized.
U.S.
consumers actually cut their spending last month for the first time in nearly two years.
Don't get your hopes up.
The economy is wounded.

It's pretty likely that the uncertainty surrounding the raising of the debt ceiling - for both businesses and consumers - has been unsettling, and just one more impediment to the full recovery that we need.
In fact, even as the president was speaking, Wall Street was tanking.
So were markets in Europe, which is struggling with a huge debt crisis of its own.
